content.webTitle: Amélie Mauresmo: I am not reliving my past through Andy Murray

fields.headline: Amélie Mauresmo: I am not reliving my past through Andy Murray
fields.bodyText: Amélie Mauresmo never enjoyed Roland Garros as much as her talent deserved. From the day she drew inspiration from Yannick Noah’s win in 1983, as a young girl watching from her home in Saint-Germain-en-Laye, just north of Paris, and all through her serial disappointments in front of her home crowd over 15 years, the French Open represented a prize too far. She got as far as the quarter-finals twice but prospered elsewhere, notably at Wimbledon and in Melbourne, and was No1 in the world for five weeks. Andy Murray, her most enduring client, has two semi-finals to show for eight visits to Paris and, on a roll of 10 clay wins and his first two titles on the dirt this summer, he has never been better placed to go further. Mauresmo insists, however, she is not reliving her past through the world No3. “For myself, yes, it was frustrating,” she said of the Tour’s second slam of the year. “For Andy, I hope not. To be honest, that’s what you guys might say. It’s not about me, to be very honest. I would be happy for him to win it; I would be happy for him to win any of the grand slams, basically, so definitely it’s not about me on this one.” Their bond after a little under a year together is strong; imbued with understanding, empathy and trust. That is why it would be a shame if this turned out to be there last big tournament together, given Mauresmo is due to give birth to her first child in August and has reservations about making the trip to London this summer – or, indeed, to Australia for the Open in January. Murray, however, who opens his campaign here on Monday against the Argentinian lucky loser Facundo Argüello, is happy with the way his assistant coach, Jonas Bjorkman, has settled in so quickly – and Mauresmo agrees the Swede is a perfect fit. “We spent a couple of days in Barcelona together,” she said. “We’re communicating quite a lot, whether it’s texting or calling, so he has an awareness of what has happened until now. Andy is my first experience as a long-term coach, so it has to be also my first experience with another coach brought in, although Dani [Vallverdu] was there last year. It takes time to adjust but so far it’s going pretty well. “The good thing is that we are both seeing the same things and both have a desire for Andy to improve in the same areas of his game. That’s really key. If you’re going to work together and have different thoughts or different things that you want to prioritise, then it might be a bit difficult. But so far, for a few months now, we’ve talked about Andy and his game – and I think we’re on the same page.” Monday is unusual in that all five British entrants will play – so the possibilities for mood swings are obvious. Kyle Edmund fancies his chances against the French qualifier Stéphane Robert – and would relish a chance to play Murray in the third round, although he would probably have to beat Nick Kyrgios on Wednesday to do so. In the other half of the draw, Aljaz Bedene, registered as British for the first time in a grand slam, has a tough opening match against the talented Austrian Dominic Thiem, although he beat him in a hardcourt Challenger tournament in Texas earlier this year. In the women’s draw, Heather Watson has found some form before her match against the French wildcard Mathilde Johansson, while Johanna Konta, who is in the same quarter, plays the Czech Denisa Allertova.
